The urgent need for sustainable hydrogen production has driven significant research into efficient electrocatalysts for water splitting. Self-supporting electrocatalysts, characterized by binder-free architectures directly integrated onto conductive substrates, offer compelling advantages over conventional powdered counterparts, including enhanced electrical conductivity, superior mass transport, mechanical stability, and efficient gas bubble release. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as good precursors for engineering such catalysts, enabling precise control over composition, morphology, and active site configuration. In this review, recent advancements in MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are summarized. We systematically analyze the design principles, synthesis strategies, and electrocatalytic performance of diverse material categories derived from MOF, including metal oxides/hydroxides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides. For each category, we discuss how unique structural features such as multiple metal active centers, optimal H* adsorption, d-electron configurations govern catalytic activity and stability. Especially, key performance-enhancement strategies, such as heteroatom doping and heterostructure engineering are analyzed. Finally, some challenges and prospects are proposed for better designing MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts to understand the structure-performance relationship and promote their practical application. Graphical Abstract Metal organic framework derived self-supporting electrocatalysts, including metal oxides/hydroxides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides are reviewed. The unique structural features such as multiple metal active centers, optimal H* adsorption, d-electron configurations on catalytic activity and stability are discussed, and key performance-enhancement strategies are analyzed. Keywords Electrocatalysis Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Metal organic frameworks Self-supporting catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen is regarded as a cornerstone for achieving decarbonization goals [1–3]. Nowadays, over 95 % of hydrogen still relies on fossil fuel-derived processes such as steam methane reforming and water-gas shift reaction, which inevitably generate CO2 emissions [4–6]. In contrast, electrochemical water splitting, offers a promising pathway to produce high-purity hydrogen using renewable electricity [7–9]. Nevertheless, the practical application of this technology is hindered by the sluggish kinetics of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [10–12]. In addition, conventional powder-based catalysts often require polymer binders for electrode fabrication, which introduce additional resistance and reduce stability [13–16]. Self-supporting electrocatalysts, grown directly on conductive substrates, offer a promising alternative by eliminating binders, enhancing electrical contact, facilitating mass transport, and improving mechanical stability [17–20]. Meanwhile, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been significantly investigated as precursors for constructing advanced electrocatalysts, owing to their ultrahigh porosity, tunable chemical compositions, and well-defined coordination environments [21–25]. MOF-derived materials inherit these merits while overcoming the intrinsic limitations of pristine MOFs such as poor electrical conductivity and instability. In addition, the inherent porosity of MOFs can be preserved or transformed into hierarchical porous architectures in derived materials, which promotes electrolyte diffusion and efficient gas bubble release-a critical factor for high-current-density operation. Meanwhile, the diversity in metal nodes and organic linkers allows for precise control over the chemical composition and electronic structure of MOF-derived catalysts. This enables the incorporation of multiple metal species and heteroatoms (N, P, S) into the catalyst framework, leading to optimized adsorption energies for reaction intermediates and enhanced intrinsic catalytic activity. Furthermore, MOFs can be engineered into various nanostructures (nanowires, nanosheets, nanotubes, and nanoarrays) through controlled synthesis conditions. These morphologies are often retained after thermal or chemical conversion into active electrocatalytic phases, providing large electrochemically active surface areas (ECSAs) and facilitating charge transfer. Significant progress has been achieved in optimizing MOFs derived self-supporting electrocatalysts and the common strategies are as follows [26–30]. (i) Engineering hierarchical nanostructures such as nanowire arrays, nanosheets to maximize accessible active sites and accelerate reaction kinetics; (ii) Optimizing the active centers such as metal oxides, metal sulfides and metal phosphides to explore their catalytic activity toward water splitting; (iii) Constructing heterostructures or heteroatom doping to induce synergistic effects and promote charge redistribution. While MOFs derived self-supporting electrocatalysts have been widely explored, systematic review focusing on this area is rare. Based on the above considerations, this review comprehensively summarizes recent breakthroughs in MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for water splitting. Beginning with fundamental reaction mechanisms and descriptor-based activity evaluation criteria for HER and OER, the progress of MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts is discussed based on substrate types, including metal oxides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides ( Fig. 1). We pay special attentions on the reasons for the improved catalytic performance such as optimized adsorption energies for intermediates, the well-designed nanostructure that enables mass transport and so on. Finally, future research directions are proposed for further development of this important area. This work aims to establish structure-activity correlations and inspire innovative solutions for designing highly efficient electrocatalysts toward green hydrogen production. 2 Reaction mechanisms of HER and OER 2.1 HER mechanisms HER means the reduction of water molecules to produce H2 at the cathode during water splitting, and it can proceed through either Volmer-Heyrovsky or Volmer-Tafel mechanism. In both reaction mechanisms, the first step is the adsorption of H on the active sites through Volmer reaction. In acidic medium, H is directly adsorbed by the active sites, while in alkaline medium, H can be produced through the decomposition of a H2O. The second step is either the adsorbed H combines one proton/H2O and an electron to form H2 (Heyrovsky reaction), or two adsorbed H atoms combine to generate H2 (Tafel reaction) [31–33]. The reaction mechanism can be described as follows, where M is the active site. Volmer reaction: (1) H3O+ + M + e- →M-H + H2O (in acidic medium) (2) H2O + M + e- →M-H + OH- (in alkaline medium) Heyrovsky reaction: (3) M-H + H3O+ + e- →H2 + H2O (in acidic medium) (4) M-H + H2O + e- →H2 + OH- (in alkaline medium) Tafel reaction: (5) 2M-H→H2 (in acidic and alkaline medium) In general, the performance of a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalyst is assessed based on the overpotential (η) needed to achieve a specific current density, as well as its Tafel slope. A low overpotential and small Tafel slope indicate that less energy input is required to drive the HER and that hydrogen generation proceeds rapidly. For fair comparison among catalysts, the overpotential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is commonly used as a benchmark, as this value corresponds to the typical output of a solar-to-fuel conversion device with around 12 % efficiency. In addition, due to the adsorbed H is involved in all the reactions, therefore the catalytic performance is governed by the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH*), which ideally should be close to zero for optimal activity [34,35]. Moreover, d-band model based on the assumption that the changes in the Kohn–Sham one-electron energies can give changes in bond energies provided a reasonable approach for calculating the bond energy between the adsorbates and the transition metals. In its most basic form, this theory uses the d-band center as a key electronic descriptor: a shift toward the Fermi level signifies stronger binding, while a shift away from it corresponds to weaker interaction. 2.2 OER mechanisms Compared with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the oxygen evolution reaction (OER)—taking place at the anode in water electrolysis—involves a more complex four-electron transfer process with multiple intermediates, such as M–OH, M–O, and M–OOH. The widely recognized reaction mechanisms in both acidic and alkaline media can be described as follows. Initially, hydroxyl ions or water molecules adsorb onto the catalyst surface, forming M–OH. This adsorbed intermediate then undergoes further electron transfer to produce M–O. Subsequently, oxygen generation may follow two possible pathways: one involves the direct coupling of two M–O species to form O2, while the other proceeds via the oxidation of M–O to M–OOH, from which O2 is eventually released [36–40]. In acidic medium: (6) M+H2O → M-OH +H++e- (7) M-OH →M-O + H+ + e- (8) 2M-O →2M + O2 (9) M-O+H2O →M-OOH + H+ + e- (10) M-OOH →M + O2 + H+ + e- In alkaline medium: (11) M+OH- →M-OH +e- (12) M-OH + OH- →M-O + H2O + e- (13) 2M-O →2 M + O2 (14) M-O+OH- →M-OOH + e- (15) M-OOH+OH- →M + O2 + H2O + e- 3 Self-supporting metal oxides and hydroxides derived from MOFs for water splitting Metal oxides and hydroxides exhibit high intrinsic activity and good stability for OER, and MOF precursors facilitate the formation of well-defined nanostructures (e.g., nanosheets, nanowires) with good substrate adhesion [41–43]. In a work, Wang et. al. reported the synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles anchored on nickel foam (Co3O4@NF) through controlled calcination of a Co-MOF@NF precursor [44]. This approach preserved the octahedral morphology of the parent MOF while inducing surface roughening, which significantly enhanced the exposure of active sites. As a result, the Co3O4@NF achieved good HER performance with overpotentials of 131 mV and 224 mV at 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively, alongside robust stability over 50 h in 1.0 M KOH. Metal-support interaction can optimize the electronic structure and catalytic activity of metal catalysts [45,46]. Using carbon cloth (CC) supported Co-MOF nanoflake as the precursor, followed by oxidation and nitrogen doping to form N-Co3O4/CC, and finally depositing ultrafine Pt nanoparticles via atomic layer deposition (ALD), Yuan et al. demonstrated an atomic-level engineering approach to enhance the HER performance of Pt-Co3O4/CC catalyst ( Fig. 2a) [47]. The nitrogen doping in Co3O4 induced lattice expansion and electronic redistribution, which synergistically modulated the electronic metal–support interaction (EMSI) at the Pt–Co3O4 interface. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that this tailored EMSI facilitated electron transfer from Pt to the N-Co3O4 support, downshifted the d-band center of Pt, and benefited the desorption of formed H2 (Fig. 2b-e). The 3D hierarchical architecture further enhanced mass transport and exposed abundant active sites. Consequently, the catalyst achieved a low overpotential of 34 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, with a mass activity of 40 times higher than commercial Pt/C, underscoring the efficacy of interface engineering in balancing catalytic efficiency and noble metal utilization. Besides for atomic-level interface engineering, defect engineering is also an effective strategy to optimize the catalytic activity, and this is demonstrated by oxygen-deficient (Fe,Co)3O4 on carbon cloth (VO-(Fe,Co)3O4@CC) [48]. The synthesis involved in situ growth of Fe/Co bimetallic MOF nanoarrays on CC, followed by pyrolysis to form (Fe,Co)3O4, and subsequent NaBH4 etching to introduce oxygen vacancies. The Fe/Co synergy optimized electronic configurations, while oxygen vacancies enhanced charge transfer kinetics and active site accessibility. As a result, VO-(Fe,Co)3O4@CC achieved a low OER overpotential of 288 mV at 10 mA cm−2. This work underscored the potential of defect engineering in improving catalytic efficiency. The role of defect engineering was also demonstrated by Sadeghi et al., who synthesized NiMo/CuO@C via in situ growth of Cu-MOF integrated with NiMo nanoparticles on Cu-coated nickel foam, followed by calcination under air at 500 °C (Fig. 2f) [49]. Due to the instability of Mo species during OER, Mo removed from the amorphous structure of NiMo and binded to oxygen, leading to NiO with high oxygen deficiency. The introduction of oxygen vacancy in NiO could facilitate water dissociation. In addition, the CuO derived Cu participates in the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen. Thus, the corresponding mechanisms is illustrated as follows. First, electrostatic attraction between Cuδ+/Niδ+ on the catalyst surface with O2− ions, along with the interaction between Ov on the catalyst surface with H+ ions, facilitated the adsorption of H2O and weakened the H−O−H bond, leading to the dissociation of adsorbed H2O into OH− and H+ ions. Then, the generated OH− ions, resulting from the dissociation of water, coordinated with Cuδ+/Niδ+ ions in the vicinity of oxygen, while H+ ions adsorbed on Ov ions undergo surface diffusion to form H2 (Fig. 2g). Due to the above reasons, the resulting catalyst exhibited a HER overpotential of 85 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH. Metal hydroxides especially layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have attracted considerable interest as electrocatalysts due to their tunable morphological, structural, and compositional features along with fabrication methods [50–52]. Heteroatom doping can be used to modify electronic structure and active site exposure [53,54]. For instance, Zheng et al. developed a Co, V-codoped FeNi-LDH electrocatalyst via a one-step hydrothermal method using ZIF-67 as the template [55]. This dual-cation incorporation not only expanded interlayer spacing but also optimized the electronic environment of Fe and Ni sites, thereby increasing its active surface area and intrinsic activity ( Fig. 3a). The Co, V-FeNi-LDH exhibited small overpotentials of 244 mV for OER at 50 mA cm−2 and 180 mV for HER at 10 mA cm−2, with a low cell voltage of 1.62 V at 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting (Fig. 3 and d). The good catalytic performance could be ascribed to the V doping that improved the conductivity of NiFe LDH, and the usage of ZIF-67 template that offered more active sites for the OER and HER due to the formation of a 3D hierarchical framework (Fig. 3c). This work underscored the efficiency of combining MOF-derived morphological control with multi-cation doping to address conductivity limitations and active site accessibility in LDH-based catalysts. Interface engineering is also a common method to modify the electronic structure of LDH-based catalysts [56–58]. Using Ni foam (NF) supported ZIF-67 as the template, Zheng et. al. firstly synthesized cobalt-nickel layered double hydroxides (CoNi-ZLDH), which was further functionalized with FeOOH nanoparticles through interfacial engineering [59] (Fig. 3e). Due to the synergistic electronic modulation between the components, including optimized charge transfer pathways, increased oxygen vacancy concentrations, and enhanced exposure of electrochemically active sites, the resulting FeOOH/CoNi-ZLDH exhibited an overpotential of 226 mV at 50 mA cm−2 for OER and an overpotential of 203 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER. In addition, FeOOH/CoNi-ZLDH only required a cell voltage of only 1.645 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 for full water splitting (Fig. 3f). The work underscored the potential of interface-engineered MOF-to-LDH transformations in tailoring electronic configurations and nano structural architectures, offering a blueprint for designing high performance electrocatalysts for water splitting. Recently, MOFs themselves have been demonstrated to be good electrocatalysts for OER. Directly using MOF as an electrocatalyst can avoid structural collapse and metal center agglomeration caused by high-temperature pyrolysis [60–62]. Nevertheless, the poor conductivity of MOFs limits their application in electrochemistry. In-situ growing MOFs on conductive support is a useful method to improve the electron transfer. In addition, due to the good catalytic activity of metal hydroxide for OER, compounding MOFs with LDH is an effective way to prepare high-performance electrocatalysts. By in-situ growing FeMn co-doped Ni(OH)2 nanosheets on nickel foam, followed by partially converting the metal hydroxides into MOF through a ligand etching strategy, Ye et. al. prepared FeMn co-doped Ni(OH)₂ nanosheets integrated with a MOF layer on nickel foam (FeMn-Ni(OH)₂@MOF/NF) ( Fig. 4a) [63]. This hierarchical architecture leveraged synergistic interactions between multi-metallic active sites (Ni, Fe, Mn) and the conductive substrate to optimize electron transfer. The sheet-on-sheet configuration, combining MOF nanosheets with hydroxide layers, enhances both electrochemical surface area and structural stability, achieving an ultralow overpotential of 199 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for OER alongside robust durability (Fig. 4b). Building upon the synergistic effects of multi-metallic active sites and hierarchical architectures demonstrated in FeMn-Ni(OH)₂@MOF/NF, recent advancements have further explored noble metal doping strategies to refine catalytic performance. A representative study is the Ir-doped Co(OH)2 nanosheets grown on ZIF-67-modified nickel foam (Ir-Co(OH)2@ZIF-67/NF) via a room-temperature soaking and hydrothermal etching approach [64]. The hierarchical nanosheet architecture, combined with the conductive NF substrate, provided a high electrochemically active surface area of 260.59 mF cm−2 and facilitated rapid bubble release. Remarkably, the catalyst achieved ultralow overpotentials of 198, 263, and 300 mV at 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2. The enhanced OER activity stems from Ir doping, which not only decreased the charge transfer resistance by modifying the partial electronic structure of Co ions and activating the partial active sites of Co ions, but also lowered the energy barrier for oxygen intermediate adsorption. In addition, the porous nanosheet morphology derived from ZIF-67 etching maximized active site exposure. This work exemplified the efficacy of integrating noble metal doping with MOF-derived structural engineering to bridge the gap between cost-effectiveness and high catalytic efficiency. The above examples highlight the advantages of integrating metal hydroxides with MOFs for water splitting. Compositing metal hydroxides with MOF derivatives is also a powerful method to improve the catalytic activity [65,66]. While hierarchical heterostructures have shown promise in rigid systems, their integration into flexible energy devices demands tailored architectures that combine mechanical resilience with bifunctional activity. By in situ growing Co-MOF on acid-treated carbon cloth (CC), flowered by pyrolyzing to form conductive Co-NC nanoflakes, and electrodeposition of NiFe-LDH, Liu et. al. prepared ultrathin NiFe-LDH nanosheets anchored on Co-embedded N-doped carbon nanoflake arrays (NiFe-LDH@Co-NC/CC) (Fig. 4c) [67]. The OER process was improved by altering the local electronic structure of the Ni and Fe species in NiFe-LDH. In addition, the ultrathin NiFe-LDH nanosheets, chemically bonded to Co-NC through C-N-Ni/Fe-O interactions, modulated electronic structures to facilitate OER kinetics. The resulting catalyst achieved exceptional catalytic activity with an OER overpotential of 284 mV at 50 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 4d). When applied in flexible Zn-air batteries, the 3D porous architecture ensured rapid mass/charge transport, delivering a peak power density of 52.91 mW cm−2 and stable cycling over 46 h under bending. This work exemplified the integration of MOF-derived conductive matrices with LDH active layers to bridge the gap between high catalytic efficiency and stability. As illustrated by the above examples, MOF-derived metal oxides and hydroxides, particularly LDHs, exhibit good OER catalytic activity, and strong integration with conductive substrates. The benefits include abundant active sites, facilitated ion intercalation, and the potential for multi-metallic synergy. However, drawbacks persist, such as moderate electrical conductivity that can limit charge transfer kinetics, possible structural collapse or agglomeration during high-temperature treatment, and the need for further clarification on the true active sites within complex polymetallic systems. In future works, it is important to reveal the reaction mechanism deeply and improve the utilization rate of active sites. 4 Self-supporting metal phosphides derived from MOFs for water splitting Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have attracted wide attention, due to their good conductivity, multi-adaptive architectures, hydrogenase-like catalytic mechanism, bifunctional catalytic activity and low cost [68–70]. In particular, CoP demonstrates a Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (△GH*) close to 0, indicating neither too strong nor too weak interaction with the intermediates [71]. The P atoms with high electronegativity can effectively capture protons and desorb the H2 product, which leads to both facilitated hydrogen adsorption and desorption processes [72]. Therefore, CoP based electrocatalysts have been widely investigated. For example, Du et. al. synthesized defect-rich CoP nanowire arrays (p-CoP/NF) via a MOF-templated strategy, which integrated structural and compositional advantages to achieve superior bifunctional activity [73]. By leveraging the hierarchical porosity and phosphorus vacancy defects introduced during the phosphorization process, the catalyst exposed abundant active sites and facilitated efficient charge/mass transport. The p-CoP/NF exhibited exceptional HER and OER performance in alkaline media, requiring ultralow overpotentials of 35 mV and 253 mV, respectively, at 10 mA cm−2. Notably, when configured in a two-electrode system, it delivered a competitive cell voltage of 1.55 V at 10 mA cm−2, demonstrating its potential for overall water splitting. Heteroatom doping is widely used to improve the catalytic performance of metal phosphides [74–76]. In a work, Dong et. al. synthesized oxygen-incorporated cobalt phosphide nanosheet arrays (O-CoP/NF) synthesized via sequential oxidation and phosphorization of Co-MOF precursors, and demonstrated the important role of oxygen-anion-incorporation [77]. The resulting O-CoP/NF exhibited remarkable bifunctional activity, achieving ultralow overpotentials of 67 mV for HER and 202 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media. Notably, the optimized O-CoP-40 variant demonstrated a cell voltage of 1.54 V for overall water splitting, coupled with exceptional stability over 36 h. The performance enhancement stemmed from the co-modulation of Co sites by electron-rich P-3p and O-2p orbitals, which synergistically lower the energy barrier for water dissociation in HER and optimize intermediate adsorption/desorption kinetics in OER. This work underscored the efficacy of anion doping in tailoring electronic environments of transition metal phosphides. Besides for anion doping, cation doped metal phosphides is more commonly investigated [78,79]. By NaVO3 etching 2D ZIF-67 on nickel foam to form V-Co layered double hydroxide (LDH), and subsequent phosphating process, Liu et. al. synthesized V-doped CoP nanosheets on NF (V-CoP-NC/NF) [80]. The optimized V5-CoP-NC/NF catalyst achieved an overpotential of 119 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER in alkaline media, surpassing undoped CoP-NC/NF (162 mV) and exhibiting robust stability over 100 h. The performance enhancement arised from dual mechanisms. Firstly, V doping induced electron redistribution between Co and P, lowering the energy barrier for H+ adsorption and water dissociation, as evidenced by XPS analysis showing shifted Co 2p and P 2p binding energies. Secondly, NaVO3 etching created hierarchical nanosheets with increased active site exposure and accelerated mass transport, while phosphating consolidated conductive N-doped carbon frameworks to facilitate charge transfer. This study underscored the complementary roles of heteroatom doping and morphological control in optimizing MOF-derived electrocatalysts. In recent advancements of MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for water splitting, innovative strategies focusing on in situ structural engineering have garnered significant attention. A notable example involves the hierarchical Co/CoP/NC (N doped carbon) nanosheets synthesized via a three-step transformation process (Co → Co(OH)2 → Co-MOF → Co/CoP/NC) directly on cobalt foam (CoF) without exogenous metal ions ( Fig. 5a) [81]. This approach leveraged endogenous Co2+ from the substrate to construct tightly bonded heterostructures, effectively minimizing interfacial impedance and enhancing electron transport. The integration of nitrogen-doped carbon with CoP optimized electronic redistribution, synergistically boosting both hydrogen and oxygen evolution activities. Remarkably, the catalyst achieved low overpotentials of 64 mV for HER and 263 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, along with good stability (Fig. 5b-c). Theoretical calculations revealed that Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption (ΔGH*) was only 0.26 eV for Co/CoP/NC/CoF, which was closer to 0 than that of CoP/CoF (ΔGH* = 0.58 eV), indicating more favorable H* adsorption and desorption kinetics of Co/CoP/NC/CoF for HER (Fig. 5d). In addition, the energy barrier of OER was 1.59 eV for Co/CoP/NC/CoF, which was also lower than that of CoP/CoF (1.68 eV), again demonstrating the advantage of the synergistic effect between CoP and NC during OER (Fig. 5e). Besides cobalt phosphide, nickel phosphide based electrocatalysts also attracted great attention, and designing multi-phase heterostructures can further improve catalytic activity and durability [82,83]. A prime example is the synthesis of Ni2P-Ni5P4-CoP-C/NF, where a pillar-layered Ni-Co-MOF was first grown on nickel foam (NF) via solvothermal reaction using NF as both the nickel source and conductive substrate [84]. Subsequent low-temperature phosphorization transformed the MOF into carbon-embedded heterostructure comprising Ni2P, Ni5P4, and CoP nanoparticles. This multi-phase architecture introduced abundant interfaces that facilitated electron redistribution, as evidenced by XPS analysis. The catalyst achieved impressive bifunctional performance, requiring overpotentials of 100 mV for HER and 293 mV for OER at 50 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, with a cell voltage of 1.55 V for overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2. Enhanced activity could be attributed to synergistic interactions between the phosphides, which optimized intermediate adsorption energies, and hierarchical pillar-layered morphology that maximized active site exposure and electrolyte diffusion. Furthermore, the carbon matrix derived from MOF ligands prevented nanoparticle aggregation and enhanced electrical conductivity. This work exemplified the strategic integration of multi-phase engineering and structural design in MOF-derived catalysts, offering a scalable approach to high-performance, cost-effective water electrolysis systems. In another work, Deng et. al. demonstrated the rational design of a heterostructured NiCoP/Ni12P5@NF catalyst derived from a novel Ni- MOF precursor, leveraging interface engineering and cobalt doping strategies [85] (Fig. 5f). The hierarchical nanosheet arrays, enriched with nitrogen-phosphorus co-doping and ultrafine phosphide nanoparticles, facilitated optimized electronic structures and abundant active sites, significantly enhancing both HER and OER kinetics. DFT calculations revealed that the heterojunction interface between NiCoP and Ni12P5 promoted electron redistribution, where an obvious charge depletion peak (11.3 Å) was observed on the Ni12P5 side of the interface of NiCoP/Ni12P5, and the charge accumulation was observed near 12.6 Å on the NiCoP side, attesting that the electrons transfered from Ni12P5 to NiCoP (Fig. 5g). In addition, d-band center of NiCoP/Ni12P5 was −1.927 eV, which shifted negatively compared with Ni2P/Ni12P5 (-1.823 eV) (Fig. 5h-j). The downward shift of the d band center weakened the strong adsorption of H* on nickel site during the HER, thereby promoting the desorption of H2 from the catalyst. Moreover, the ΔGH* for NiCoP/Ni12P5 and Ni2P/Ni12P5 were 0.017 and 0.313 eV, respectively, suggesting a smaller energy barrier in NiCoP/Ni12P5 (Fig. 5i-l). Due to the above reasons, the NiCoP/Ni12P5 only needed overpotentials of 100 mV for HER and 310 mV for OER at 10 mAcm−2, and could enable stable operation in anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyzers for over 200 h at industrial-grade current densities (100 mA cm−2). This work exemplified the synergistic integration of interface engineering and heteroatom doping to address challenges in catalytic activity and durability. Besides cobalt phosphide and nickel phosphide based electrocatalysts, recent research further focused on iron phosphide [86,87]. In a work, Zhang et. al. synthesized FeP/NF through a sequential electrodeposition-solvothermal-phosphorization strategy [88]. Initially, an Fe film was electrodeposited on nickel foam, followed by MIL-88A growth via solvothermal treatment with fumaric acid, and subsequent controlled phosphidation at varying temperatures (350–550°C). The optimized FeP-350/NF catalyst, featuring moss-like particles with a high surface area and strong substrate adhesion, demonstrated exceptional bifunctional activity in alkaline media, achieving low overpotentials of 154 mV for OER and 122 mV for HER at 10 mA cm−2. Notably, its integrated two-electrode system required only 1.54 V for overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 and maintained stability over 24 h. The enhanced performance stemed from the synergistic effects of the MIL-88A-derived porous framework, which facilitated efficient mass/charge transport, and the in-situ formation of FeP with optimized crystallinity and surface oxidation states. Expanding the design principles of MOF-derived phosphides, recent advancements highlight the efficacy of bimetallic systems in optimizing electronic configurations and active site distribution. A notable example is the synthesis of NiFeP nanosheets on carbon cloth (NiFeP@CC) through in situ solvothermal growth of NiFe-MOF (MIL-88) nanosheets on carbon cloth, followed by controlled phosphorization at 350 °C [89] ( Fig. 6a). This process yielded a hierarchical architecture comprising interconnected 2D NiFeP nanosheets anchored on a conductive 3D carbon substrate. The optimized NiFeP@CC exhibited exceptional OER performance in alkaline media, achieving a low overpotential of 229 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The enhanced activity can be ascribed to the synergistic Ni-Fe interactions, which modulated d-band energy levels to favor intermediate adsorption, and the in-situ formation of NiFeP/NiFe2O4 heterostructures that facilitate charge transfer via built-in electric fields (Fig. 6b-e). In another work, a CoFeP/NF catalyst was synthesized via an electrodeposition-assisted hydrothermal method, where ZIF-67-Fe nanosheets were first grown on NF, followed by controlled phosphorization [90]. The resulting CoFeP/NF exhibited bifunctional catalytic activity in alkaline media, achieving overpotentials of 204 mV for OER and 350 mV for HER at 50 mA cm−2. The enhanced performance could be ascribed to the synergistic interplay between Co and Fe, which optimized electronic configurations to lower energy barriers for intermediate adsorption, coupled with the hierarchical porosity inherited from the MOF precursor that facilitated electrolyte infiltration and gas release. Trimetallic phosphides have been developed based on the synergy of different metals, and combining other strategy such as defect engineering can further improve their catalytic activity. By converting CC supported Co-MOF into NiCoFe LDH/MOF composites, followed by phosphorization using NaH2PO2 at 350 °C, Xiao et. al. prepared hierarchical Ni-Fe-Co-P nanowire arrays on CC [91] (Fig. 6f). The unique architecture, characterized by interconnected nanosheets and three-dimensional porosity, not only enhanced mass/charge transport but also exposed numerous active sites, addressing common limitations of conventional powder-based catalysts. Crucially, the synergistic interplay between ternary metals and phosphorus vacancies modulated the electronic structure, thereby optimizing adsorption energetics for both hydrogen and oxygen intermediates (Fig. 6g-h). The resultant catalyst achieved remarkable bifunctionality, requiring low overpotentials of 106 mV for HER and 249 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, with a cell voltage of 1.62 V for overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2. Using a protective coating strategy, a recent work demonstrated the importance of interfacial engineering in stabilizing MOF-derived electrocatalysts under harsh electrochemical conditions. Beginning with the hydrothermal growth of CoNiFe-CH nanoneedles on nickel foam, followed by ZIF-L coating at room temperature, Cui et. al. synthesized hierarchical CoNiFeP nanorods via phosphorization of CoNiFe-CH@ZIF-L at 300 °C [92]. The resultant catalyst exhibited exceptional bifunctional activity, achieving remarkably low overpotentials of 168 mV for HER and 236 mV for OER at 100 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH, alongside outstanding durability (>500 h for OER at 100 mA cm−2). This performance enhancement was attributed to three synergistic factors: (1) the preserved nanoneedle architecture ensured high surface area and efficient gas diffusion; (2) the ternary Co-Ni-Fe system optimized electronic interactions, reducing energy barriers for intermediate adsorption; and (3) the ZIF-L-derived carbon matrix enhanced structural integrity and charge transfer kinetics. The above two examples demonstrated the potential of multi-metallic phosphides, by using the synergy effect of different metals. It should be point out that high-entropy electrocatalysts show improved catalytic activity due to the high-entropy effect, sluggish diffusion effect, lattice distortion effect and cocktail effect, while self-supporting high-entropy electrocatalysts developed from MOFs are rare. It is except that by designing high-entropy electrocatalysts through introducing more elements, the catalytic performance can be further improved. Recent investigations have demonstrated the potential of MOFs themselves as self-supporting catalysts for OER [93,94]. Combined with the good catalytic activity of metal phosphides, the potential of MOF/metal phosphide composites have been explored. In a work, Ni2P@Ni-MOF/NF was synthesized via a solvothermal growth of Ni-MOF nanosheets on nickel foam, followed by controlled partial phosphidation at 300°C [95]. This strategy preserved the porous MOF framework while embedding ultrafine Ni2P nanoparticles within the nanosheets, balancing structural integrity with enhanced conductivity. The resulting hybrid catalyst exhibited exceptional bifunctional performance, requiring only 1.41 V (vs RHE) for urea oxidation (UOR) at 100 mA cm−2 and a low HER overpotential of 66 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The retained MOF matrix facilitated gas bubble detachment due to its hierarchical porosity, while the Ni2P nanoparticles optimized charge transfer and provided abundant active sites. XPS analysis confirmed electron redistribution between Ni and P, enhancing adsorption energetics. This study highlighted the synergistic benefits of combining MOF-derived nanostructures with partial phosphidation, offering a pathway to tailor catalytic interfaces for electrocatalytic reactions. The potential of MOFs and metal phosphides composites was also investigated by Cao et. al., who constructed heterostructured NiCoP/ZIF-67/NF electrode, using ZIF-67 nanosheets grown on nickel foam as a substrate for amorphous NiCoP deposition via electrodeposition [96] ( Fig. 7a). This architecture leveraged the synergistic interplay between ZIF-67 and NiCoP. ZIF-67 provided a high surface area and abundant Co sites, while NiCoP enhanced conductivity and introduced additional Ni/Co active centers. XPS and in situ Raman spectroscopy revealed that the electrochemical reconstruction of NiCoP and ZIF-67 under alkaline conditions generated NiOOH/CoOOH heterostructures as the true active species, which significantly reduce the energy barrier for oxygen evolution. The optimized catalyst achieved an overpotential of 175 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and sustains stable operation for 40 h (Fig. 7b). Benefiting from their hydrogenase-like mechanism, compositional flexibility allowing for heteroatom doping, and the formation of conductive carbon matrices in situ, TMPs derived from MOFs achieved great progress. Nevertheless, the drawbacks of TMPs are also obvious. Firstly, the synthesis often involves hazardous phosphorus sources such as NaH2PO2. In addition, controlling phase purity and specific active phases (e.g., Ni2P vs. Ni12P5) during phosphorization is also difficult. Therefore, developing mild and controllable synthetic method for TMPs is important. 5 Self-supporting metal sulfides derived from MOFs for water splitting Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are very promising alternatives due to their unique physicochemical properties including various crystal structures, different crystal phases and adjustable band position and band gap [97–100]. Though the conductivity of TMSs is not high, the preparation of self-supporting TMSs can avoid the usage of polymer binder and boost electronic transfer. A notable advancement in the development of self-supporting metal sulfides is the work reported by Guan et. al., where CoS2 nanotube arrays (NTA) was synthesized by reacting with thioacetamide and thermal annealing in N2 using wire-like MOF nanoarrays as the precursor [101] ( Fig. 8a). This innovative approach resulted in a hierarchically porous and mechanically robust architecture. The hollow tubular configuration enhanced electrolyte accessibility and gas diffusion, while the intrinsic nanograin boundaries within the CoS2 walls provided abundant active sites for both OER and HER. Crucially, the direct integration of CoS2 NTA/CC with the conductive substrate eliminated the need for binders, ensuring efficient electron transfer and structural durability even under mechanical stress. The CoS2 NTA/CC achieved overpotentials of 276 mV for OER and 193 mV for HER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, along with a cell voltage of 1.67 V for overall water splitting, demonstrating the potential of MOF derived metal sulfides for water splitting (Fig. 8b). Transitioning from alkaline to acidic environments, another example of MOF-derived self-supported metals sulfides is Co9S8-decorated carbon nanofibers (Co-NSC@CBC), which synthesized by growing ZIF-67 on polydopamine-modified bacterial cellulose (PDA/BC), followed by pyrolysis and sulfidation [102]. The PDA layer ensured uniform anchoring of ZIF-67 on the BC substrate, while subsequent thermal treatment converted the MOF precursor into Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded within a carbonized bacterial cellulose (CBC) network. Electrochemical evaluations in 0.5 M H2SO4 revealed exceptional HER performance, with a low overpotential of 138 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 123 mV dec−1, along with good stability for more than 120 h. The enhanced activity stemmed from synergistic interactions between Co9S8 and the CBC substrate, which optimized electronic structure and exposed abundant active sites. Additionally, controlled sulfidation conditions mitigated excessive S-H bond formation, balancing catalytic efficiency and stability. Besides cobalt sulfides, the OER catalytic activity of nickle sulfides are also investigated. For example, using NF supported Ni-MOF as the precursor, Wu et. al. investigated the effect of sulfur source on structure and catalytic activity of the obtained catalysts [103]. It is found that using thiourea as sulfur source, the MOF was partially converted to sulfide (Ni-MOF/NF-Tu), while Na2S and thioacetamide can fully transformed MOF into Ni-based sulfide (Ni-MOF/NF-SS, and Ni-MOF/NF-TAA). In addition, Ni-MOF/NF-SS exhibited the best catalytic activity, with an overpotential of 253 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 70.9 mV dec−1 in 1 M KOH. The superior activity stems from optimized electronic interactions between Ni and S, where Na2S induces favorable d-band modulation and facilitates in situ surface reconstruction into NiOOH/Ni(OH)2 during OER, which identified as the true catalytic phase. Additionally, the self-supported architecture eliminated binder-induced resistance, ensuring rapid charge transfer and structural durability over 50 h of operation. This work underscored the pivotal role of sulfur source selection in tailoring phase composition, electronic states, and interfacial dynamics, providing a strategic blueprint for designing MOF-derived sulfides with application-specific catalytic functionalities. Heterostructure catalysts with various composite offers opportunities for optimizing the electronic structure of electrocatalysts, thereby improving their catalytic performance [104,105]. Using Ni foam supported urchin-like Co-MOF as the precursor, Bu et. al. synthesized urchin-like Co9S8-Ni3S2 composites with optimized heterointerfaces on Ni foam via a solvothermal strategy (Fig. 8c) [106]. This architecture leveraged the inherent porosity of MOFs to maximize active site exposure and facilitate rapid mass/charge transfer, while the electronic interplay between Co9S8 and Ni3S2 enhanced intrinsic OER activity. The optimized catalyst achieved an overpotential of 233 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and robust stability over 12 h (Fig. 8d). MoS2 has been widely investigated for HER due to its layered structure and Pt-like electronic structure [107–110]. The active sites of MoS2 mainly locate on the edge, and its basal plane is inert. Therefore, activating the basal plane of MoS2 and increasing its exposed active sites are powerful method to improve its catalytic activity. Heteroatom doping and interface engineering are commonly used method, and MOFs are also used as precursor for preparing MoS2 based catalysts. For example, Chen et. al. synthesized carbon cloth (CC) supported hollow Co–MoS2 by hydrothermal reaction of Co-MOF with sodium molybdate and thiourea, and achieved a current density of 1500 mA cm−2 at 296 mV overpotential in acidic media [111]. The performance enhancement could be ascribed to multiple synergistic factors: the hollow morphology facilitated electrolyte diffusion and rapid hydrogen bubble detachment, the carbon nanowire arrays enhanced electrical conductivity, and Co doping modulated the electronic structure of MoS2, activating basal planes and edge sites. Furthermore, the direct growth of Co–MoS2 on CC minimized charge transfer resistance and stabilized the catalytic interface during prolonged operation. Integration of multi-metallic components and structural engineering can greatly improve the catalytic activity. Using nickel foam (NF) supported MIL-53(FeNi) as a sacrificial template, Wang et al. synthesized Ni3S2/MoS2/Fe3S4 heterostructure on NF by hydrothermal reaction using ammonium molybdate and thioacetamide as Mo and S sources ( Fig. 9a) [112]. The hierarchical architecture, featuring vertically aligned nanoflowers with ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets, leveraged the synergistic interactions between ternary sulfides to optimize charge transfer and expose abundant active sites. Ni3S2/MoS2/Fe3S4 achieved a remarkably low HER overpotential of 54 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, alongside robust durability (Fig. 9b). This work underscored the potential of MOF-guided synthesis in tailoring multi-component sulfides with tailored morphologies and electronic configurations, offering insights into scalable fabrication of high-performance, non-precious metal electrodes for sustainable hydrogen production. Phase engineering and defect modulation have been used to further improve the electrocatalytic performance of multi-metallic sulfides, combining with self-supporting nature to boost gas release [113,114]. In a recent work, Chen et al. synthesized self-supported 1T-MoS2/Co3S4/Ni3S2 nanoarrays via a ZIF-67-derived strategy on nickel foam (NF) (Fig. 9c) [115]. The hierarchical architecture was constructed through sequential ion exchange and sulfidation processes, where ZIF-67 served as a precursor for the formation of CoMoO4, which was subsequently transformed into Co3S4 and metallic 1T-MoS2, while NF itself contributed to Ni3S2 formation. The resulting heterostructure featured vertically aligned nanosheets with abundant interfaces and lattice defects, as confirmed by TEM and XPS analyses. These structural features synergistically enhanced charge transfer kinetics, exposed additional active sites, and optimized adsorption energetics for both HER and OER. Remarkably, the catalyst achieved ultralow overpotentials of 50 mV for HER and 240 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media, while enabling efficient overall water splitting at a cell voltage of 1.55 V (Fig. 9d). For developing self-supporting electrocatalysts, recent studies have focused on enhancing catalytic durability and activity under industrial-relevant conditions, as exemplified by the hierarchical Co4S3/Fe3S4/MoS2 nanosheet arrays grown on iron foam (IF) [116]. This trimetallic sulfide system was synthesized via a solvothermal sulfurization strategy in the presence of Na2MoO4 and CH3CSNH2, by using FeCo-MOF as the precursor. The IF substrate served dual roles as a conductive scaffold and Fe source, enabling in situ growth of vertically aligned nanosheets. The optimized catalyst demonstrated exceptional bifunctionality, achieving overpotentials of 241 mV for HER and 220 mV for OER at 100 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, alongside a low cell voltage of 1.26 V at 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting. Remarkably, in alkaline simulated seawater, the system maintained robust performance with a minimal voltage of 1.45 V at 10 mA cm−2 and sustained stability over 48 h. The enhanced activity could be attributed to the Co4S3/Fe3S4/MoS2 heterostructure that facilitated electron transfer and OER intermediates adsorption, and MoS2 that enriched HER-active edge sites and optimized hydrogen adsorption energy. Additionally, the 3D nanosheet architecture ensured rapid gas release and electrolyte penetration, which were critical for high-current-density operation. Building on the advancements in heterostructure engineering, recent efforts have focused on coupling MOFs with conductive sulfides to address kinetic limitations in alkaline hydrogen evolution [117]. For example, Cheng et al. developed a hierarchical Ni3S2@2D Co-MOF/CP catalyst via a two-step strategy involving room-temperature crystallization of ultrathin Co-MOF nanosheets on carbon paper (CP), followed by in-situ electrodeposition of Ni3S2 nanosheets [118]. The Co-MOF framework served as a structural scaffold to prevent Ni3S2 agglomeration while introducing defect-rich oxygen sites that lowered the energy barrier for water dissociation. XPS analysis revealed electron transfer from Co-MOF to Ni3S2, endowing the sulfide with an electron-rich surface that weakened H* adsorption and facilitated H2 desorption. This synergistic interplay enabled the catalyst to achieve a low HER overpotential of 140 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Notably, the binder-free electrode maintains stability over 2000 cycles due to strong interfacial coupling between components. This work highlighted the efficacy of integrating 2D MOFs with conductive sulfides through precise interfacial engineering, offering a scalable pathway to design robust electrodes for industrial-scale alkaline water electrolysis. The integration of MOFs with transition metal sulfides is also demonstrated by Wang’s work, where Fe-based MOF-Ni3S2 heterostructure was synthesized on nickel foam (NF), to exemplify the synergistic advantages of combining crystalline and amorphous phases ( Fig. 10a) [119]. This catalyst leveraged the high conductivity of Ni3S2 and the abundant active sites provided by the amorphous Fe-MOF, enabling efficient charge transfer and enhanced reaction kinetics. Remarkably, the heterostructure achieved ultralow overpotentials of 243, 283, and 309 mV at 100, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 10b). The self-supporting architecture eliminated binder-induced resistance, while the robust interface between MOF and sulfide phases ensured exceptional stability under high current densities, with negligible activity loss over 20 h. In another work, Su et al. synthesized a bifunctional Ni–S/Co-MOF/NF electrocatalyst, where 3D flower-like Co-MOF nanosheets were first grown on nickel foam (NF), followed by in-situ deposition of Ni-S nanoparticles (Fig. 10c) [120]. The hierarchical architecture combined the porous framework of Co-MOF with conductive Ni-S, offering abundant accessible active sites and efficient charge/mass transport pathways. XPS analysis revealed electron redistribution at the Ni–S/Co-MOF interface, optimizing adsorption energetics for both H* and oxygen intermediates. This synergy coupled with the binder-free design, enabled the catalyst to achieve low overpotentials of 127 mV for HER and 248 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, alongside a cell voltage of 1.59 V for overall water splitting (Fig. 10d). The 3D flower-like morphology not only enhanced structural stability during prolonged operation (>70 h) but also mitigated gas bubble accumulation, ensuring sustained catalytic activity at high current densities. This work exemplified the importance of integrating conductive sulfides with MOF scaffolds in three-dimensional configurations, bridging the gap between nanoscale electronic modulation and macroscopic electrode engineering for scalable water electrolysis. MOF-derived TMSs are attractive due to their diverse crystalline phases, tunable electronic structures, and high electrochemical activity. The benefits include the versatility of sulfur sources for synthesis, the ability to form complex heterostructures with synergistic effects, and good HER performance, especially with MoS2-based catalysts. The primary drawbacks involve the relatively lower OER activity compared to oxides/hydroxides, and the instability of sulfur vacancies and sulfur species under anodic potentials leading to surface reconstruction and potential catalyst dissolution. Though the reconstruction mechanisms have been partially explored by recent works, it is still important to clarify the actual active sites and the reasons for the changed catalytic activity. 6 Self-supporting metal selenides derived from MOFs for water splitting As another important kind of metal chalcogenides, transition metal selenides with the merits of excellent stability, high robustness, low cost, and high electrical conductivity are regarded as a newly promising alternative to noble metals toward water splitting [121,122]. In addition, the 3d orbital of Se may be contributed in bonding with metal atoms because of its energy level being near the 3p and 3 s orbitals, leading to more metallicity in metal selenides. Based on the versatility of MOFs, the integration of multi-metallic selenides represents a promising avenue for optimizing self-supported electrocatalysts. A compelling example is the work by Liu et al., which demonstrated the synthesis of Cu–Ni–Se nanostructures on carbon cloth (Cu–Ni–Se@CC) via a two-step process involving hydrothermal growth of bimetallic Cu-Ni-MOF nano rectangles and subsequent selenization under Se vapor at 350°C [123]. The transformation from MOF precursors to selenides yielded a hierarchical nanograss morphology with uniformly distributed Cu, Ni, and Se, while retaining the original rectangular framework to ensure structural robustness. This unique architecture provided a high specific surface area and mesoporous channels, facilitating electrolyte penetration and active site accessibility. The Cu–Ni–Se@CC exhibited exceptional OER performance, requiring an overpotential of only 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. The enhanced activity stemmed from synergistic electronic modulation between Cu and Ni, where Cu incorporation redistributed charge density at the NiSe2 interface, optimizing OH⁻ adsorption and accelerating O2 generation kinetics. Additionally, the self-supported design eliminated binder-induced resistance, further improving charge transfer efficiency and long-term stability. In another representative study, hollow (Ni, Co)Se2 arrays with a triangular morphology were synthesized via a three-step strategy involving MOF templating, Ni2+-mediated ion exchange/etching, and solvothermal selenization ( Fig. 11a) [124]. The cobalt-based MOF precursor, grown on carbon cloth (CC), underwent structural evolution to form a hollow NiCo-layered double hydroxide intermediate, which was subsequently converted into (Ni, Co)Se2 while retaining its hierarchical architecture. This unique hollow structure, combined with the synergistic electronic interaction between Ni and Co, significantly enhanced charge transfer and exposed abundant active sites. As an OER catalyst, the (Ni, Co)Se2/CC achieved a low overpotential of 256 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 11b). Constructing heterostructure in metal selenides is also used to improve their catalytic activity. A notable example is the development of porous CoSe2–MoSe2 heterojunction nanosheet arrays synthesized via ion exchange and vapor-phase selenization using Co-MOF as a structural template (Fig. 11c) [125]. This approach leveraged the inherent porosity and tunable morphology of MOFs to construct a bimetallic selenide heterostructure anchored on carbon cloth (CC), which synergistically combined high conductivity, abundant active sites, and optimized interfacial charge redistribution. The resulting catalyst exhibited exceptional OER performance, achieving an overpotential of 278 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline media (Fig. 11d). Key structural advantages include a hierarchical porous architecture that facilitated rapid mass/charge transfer and gas diffusion, as well as strong electronic coupling between CoSe2 and MoSe2 phases that lowered the energy barrier. The above examples demonstrated the importance of different metal centers and interface engineering in improving the catalytic activity of metal selenides, offer opportunities for their applications in energy conversion. MOF-derived metal selenides boast high electronic conductivity, and favorable kinetics for both HER and OER. The benefits include the metallicity of selenides, the ease of introducing vacancies or dopants, and the strong synergy in multi-metallic selenides. However, drawbacks should not be overlooked. The toxicity of common selenium sources (e.g., Se powder, H2Se) poses safety and environmental concerns for large-scale synthesis. The understanding of their surface evolution and active states under operating conditions, especially for OER, is less established compared to oxides or phosphides. Furthermore, the long-term durability under high anodic potentials requires more thorough investigation. 7 Conclusions and perspectives Self-supporting electrocatalysts represent a significant advancement in water splitting technology, eliminating the need for inactive binders and conductive additives while offering enhanced electrical conductivity, superior mechanical stability, and direct pathways for mass/electron transport. MOFs have emerged as exceptionally versatile precursors for crafting such catalysts, enabling precise control over composition, morphology, and structure. Recent years have witnessed remarkable progress in developing high-performance MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for both HER and OER. This review comprehensively summarized the design, synthesis, and application of MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. We specifically detailed the development and electrocatalytic merits of diverse material categories derived from MOF nanoarrays, including metal oxides/hydroxides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides ( Table 1). For each category, the evolution in synthetic strategies, unique structural advantages, and resulting catalytic performance were discussed. Furthermore, we critically examined key strategies employed to significantly boost catalytic activity and stability. Heteroatoms doping was highlighted as a powerful method to fine-tune the electronic structure of active sites, thereby enhancing intrinsic activity. Similarly, the construction of heterostructures was shown to synergistically combine the strengths of different components, create highly active heterogeneous interfaces, and improve overall catalyst durability. Despite these substantial achievements, several critical challenges must be addressed to propel MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts towards practical implementation. (i) Limited precursor diversity. The current reliance on a narrow range of MOF precursors (primarily ZIF-type Co-MOFs) restricts material diversity. Exploring abundant, low-cost MOFs with facile, scalable synthesis routes is crucial for expanding the library of derivable functional materials. (ii) Synthesis optimization. Harsh synthesis conditions, particularly high-temperature pyrolysis for carbon composites, often compromise porosity and active site density. Developing milder, energy-efficient methods and balancing pyrolysis parameters to preserve structure is essential. Similarly, simplifying the synthesis of sulfides, phosphides, selenides, and nitrides is needed. A deeper understanding of the true active sites within complex polymetallic oxides/hydroxides is also required. (iii) Cost and atom efficiency. Strategies involving noble metal doping, while effective, increase catalyst costs prohibitively. Future efforts must focus on minimizing noble metal content while maximizing atom utilization efficiency. Recently, MOFs derived metal-based catalysts with small clusters even single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been extensively investigated as powder materials, while the related investigation as self-supporting catalysts is rare. It is expected that by improving the atom utilization efficiency, higher catalytic performance can be achieved. (iv) MOF/derivatives composites. One of the most advantages is their high specific surface area and uniform active sites, and post treatment will inevitably lead to the collapse of the structure and the destruction of active sites. Therefore, developing MOF/derivatives composite catalysts that combining both the advantage of MOF and their derivatives can be a strategy to improve the catalytic activity. In addition, due to the specific surface area of catalysts plays a critical role in their performance, a systematic investigation on the surface area between parent MOF and derived materials is also important. (v) Mechanistic Understanding. A more profound comprehension of structure-performance relationships necessitates advanced in situ/operando characterization techniques combined with sophisticated theoretical calculations to unveil the dynamic processes and true active states during catalysis. (vi) Obstacles for commercialization. Several formidable challenges must be overcome to transition MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts from laboratory prototypes to commercially viable components in industrial water electrolyzers. Firstly, the scalable production of MOF precursors and their derived catalysts remains a primary hurdle. Many MOFs require expensive organic ligands and solvents, prolonged reaction times, and precise conditions that are difficult to maintain on a large scale. Secondly, while many catalysts demonstrate good stability in laboratory tests, industrial electrolyzers require operation for thousands of hours at much higher current densities (≥500 mA cm−2). The structural and chemical stability of MOF-derived catalysts-especially phosphides, sulfides, and selenides-under these harsh anodic (for OER) conditions is not yet fully validated. Surface oxidation, dissolution of non-noble metal species, corrosion of the catalytic layer, and delamination from the substrate are critical issues that must be addressed through more rigorous testing. Thirdly, the regeneration and recyclability of the catalysts are rarely investigated in current literatures, which is also important for their practical applications. We firmly believe that overcoming these challenges is well within reach. Continuous advancements in nanomaterial design, sophisticated characterization tools, and scalable manufacturing technologies will drive the next wave of innovation in MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts. The precise engineering of single-atom sites, the exploration of novel MOF precursors and derivative materials (like nitrides), and the integration of computational design with experimental synthesis hold immense promise. As research progresses, these efficient and durable catalysts are poised to transition from laboratory breakthroughs to cornerstone components of commercial water electrolyzers. Through persistent and collaborative efforts, MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts will play a pivotal role in realizing the sustainable and economical production of green hydrogen, contributing significantly to a future clean energy economy. coredata.dc:description: The urgent need for sustainable hydrogen production has driven significant research into efficient electrocatalysts for water splitting. Self-supporting electrocatalysts, characterized by binder-free architectures directly integrated onto conductive substrates, offer compelling advantages over conventional powdered counterparts, including enhanced electrical conductivity, superior mass transport, mechanical stability, and efficient gas bubble release. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as good precursors for engineering such catalysts, enabling precise control over composition, morphology, and active site configuration. In this review, recent advancements in MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are summarized. We systematically analyze the design principles, synthesis strategies, and electrocatalytic performance of diverse material categories derived from MOF, including metal oxides/hydroxides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides. For each category, we discuss how unique structural features such as multiple metal active centers, optimal H* adsorption, d-electron configurations govern catalytic activity and stability. Especially, key performance-enhancement strategies, such as heteroatom doping and heterostructure engineering are analyzed. Finally, some challenges and prospects are proposed for better designing MOF-derived self-supporting electrocatalysts to understand the structure-performance relationship and promote their practical application.
